content.rendered: Ruby is a dynamic, reflective, general purpose, open source programming language that focuses on simplicity and productivity. Ruby has a mixed features of Perl, small talk, Eiffel, Ada and Lisp. Ruby was designed to create a new language which makes a balance with the functionality of Imperative languages.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby is a dynamic, reflective, general purpose, open source programming language that focuses on simplicity and productivity. Ruby has a mixed features of Perl, small talk, Eiffel, Ada and Lisp. Ruby was designed to create a new language which makes a balance with the functionality of Imperative languages.

title.rendered: Who is the developer of Ruby?

content.rendered: Ruby is designed and developed by Yukihiro “martz” Matsumoto in mid 1990 in Japan.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby is designed and developed by Yukihiro “martz” Matsumoto in mid 1990 in Japan.

title.rendered: Why Ruby is known as a language of flexibility?

content.rendered: Ruby is known as a language of flexibility because it facilitates its author to alter the programming elements. Some specific parts of the language can be removed or redefined. Ruby does not restrict the user. For example, to add two numbers, Ruby allows to use + sign or the word ‘plus’. This alteration can be done with Ruby’s built-in class Numeric.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby is known as a language of flexibility because it facilitates its author to alter the programming elements. Some specific parts of the language can be removed or redefined. Ruby does not restrict the user. For example, to add two numbers, Ruby allows to use + sign or the word ‘plus’. This alteration can be […]

content.rendered:
Ruby has many features. Some of them are listed below.

  • Object-oriented
  • Flexible
  • Dynamic typing and Duck typing
  • Garbage collector
  • Keyword arguments

excerpt.rendered: Ruby has many features. Some of them are listed below. Object-oriented Flexible Dynamic typing and Duck typing Garbage collector Keyword arguments

title.rendered: Explain some differences between Ruby and Python.

content.rendered:
Similarities:

  • High level language
  • Support multiple platforms
  • Use interactive prompt called irb
  • Server side scripting language

Differences:

  • Ruby is fully object oriented while Python is not.
  • Ruby supports EclipseIDE while Python supports multiple IDEs.
  • Ruby use Mixins while Python doesn’t.
  • Ruby supports blocks, procs and lambdas while Python doesn’t.

excerpt.rendered: Similarities: High level language Support multiple platforms Use interactive prompt called irb Server side scripting language Differences: Ruby is fully object oriented while Python is not. Ruby supports EclipseIDE while Python supports multiple IDEs. Ruby use Mixins while Python doesn’t. Ruby supports blocks, procs and lambdas while Python doesn’t.

title.rendered: What are class libraries in Ruby?

content.rendered:
Ruby class libraries contain variety of domain such as thread programming, data types, various domains. Following is a list of domains which has relevant class libraries:

  • Text processing
  • CGI Programming
  • Network programming
  • GUI programming
  • XML programming

excerpt.rendered: Ruby class libraries contain variety of domain such as thread programming, data types, various domains. Following is a list of domains which has relevant class libraries: Text processing CGI Programming Network programming GUI programming XML programming

title.rendered: Name some operators used in Ruby.

content.rendered:
Operators are a symbol which is used to perform different operations.

  • Unary operator
  • Airthmetic operator
  • Bitwise operator
  • Logical operator
  • Ternary operator

excerpt.rendered: Operators are a symbol which is used to perform different operations. Unary operator Airthmetic operator Bitwise operator Logical operator Ternary operator

title.rendered: What is RubyGems in Ruby programming language?

content.rendered: RubyGems provides a standard format for distributing ruby programs and libraries. It works as a package manager for the Ruby programming language.

excerpt.rendered: RubyGems provides a standard format for distributing ruby programs and libraries. It works as a package manager for the Ruby programming language.

content.rendered:
Ruby variables hold data which can be used later in a program. Each variable act as a memory and shas a different name.

There are four types of variables in Ruby:

  • Local variable
  • Class variable
  • Instance variable
  • Global variable

excerpt.rendered: Ruby variables hold data which can be used later in a program. Each variable act as a memory and shas a different name. There are four types of variables in Ruby: Local variable Class variable Instance variable Global variable

title.rendered: What is the difference between nil and false in Ruby?

excerpt.rendered: nil false nil cannot be a value. false can be a value. nil is returned where there is no predicate. in case of a predicate, true or false is returned by a method. nil is not a boolean data type. false is a boolean data type. nil is an object of nilclass. false is an […]

content.rendered:
Ruby data types represent type of data such as text, string, numbers, etc.

There are different data types in Ruby:

  • Numbers
  • Strings
  • Symbols
  • Hashes
  • Arrays
  • Booleans

excerpt.rendered: Ruby data types represent type of data such as text, string, numbers, etc. There are different data types in Ruby: Numbers Strings Symbols Hashes Arrays Booleans

title.rendered: What is the use of load and require in Ruby?

content.rendered: In Ruby, load and require both are used for loading the available code into the current code. In cases where loading the code required every time when changed or every times someone hits the URL, it is suggested to use ‘load’.

excerpt.rendered: In Ruby, load and require both are used for loading the available code into the current code. In cases where loading the code required every time when changed or every times someone hits the URL, it is suggested to use ‘load’.

content.rendered:
The Ruby if-else statement is used to test condition. There are various types of statement in Ruby.

  • if statement
  • if-else statement
  • if-else-if (elsif) statement
  • ternary statement

excerpt.rendered: The Ruby if-else statement is used to test condition. There are various types of statement in Ruby. if statement if-else statement if-else-if (elsif) statement ternary statement

content.rendered: In Ruby, we use ‘case’ instead of ‘switch’ and ‘when’ instead of ‘case’. The case statement matches one statement with multiple conditions just like a switch statement in other languages.

excerpt.rendered: In Ruby, we use ‘case’ instead of ‘switch’ and ‘when’ instead of ‘case’. The case statement matches one statement with multiple conditions just like a switch statement in other languages.

content.rendered:
Ruby for loop iterates over a specific range of numbers. Hence, for loop is used if a program has fixed number of itrerations.

Ruby for loop will execute once for each element in expression.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby for loop iterates over a specific range of numbers. Hence, for loop is used if a program has fixed number of itrerations. Ruby for loop will execute once for each element in expression.

content.rendered:
Ruby while loop is used to iterate a program several times. If the number of iterations is not fixed

for a program, while loop is used.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby while loop is used to iterate a program several times. If the number of iterations is not fixed for a program, while loop is used.

title.rendered: Explain do while loop in Ruby.

content.rendered: Ruby do while loop iterates a part of program several times. In this, loop will execute at least once because do while condition is written at the end.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby do while loop iterates a part of program several times. In this, loop will execute at least once because do while condition is written at the end.

content.rendered: Ruby until loop runs until the given condition evaluates to true. It exits the loop when condition becomes true. It is opposite of the while loop.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby until loop runs until the given condition evaluates to true. It exits the loop when condition becomes true. It is opposite of the while loop.

content.rendered: Ruby break statement is used to terminate a loop. It is mostly used in while loop where value is printed till the condition is true.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby break statement is used to terminate a loop. It is mostly used in while loop where value is printed till the condition is true.

content.rendered: Ruby next statement is used to skip loop’s next iteration. Once the next statement is executed, no further iteration will be performed.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby next statement is used to skip loop’s next iteration. Once the next statement is executed, no further iteration will be performed.

content.rendered: Ruby redo statement is used to repeat the current iteration of the loop. The redo statement is executed without evaluating loop’s condition.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby redo statement is used to repeat the current iteration of the loop. The redo statement is executed without evaluating loop’s condition.

content.rendered: Ruby retry statement is used to repeat the whole loop iteration from the start.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby retry statement is used to repeat the whole loop iteration from the start.

title.rendered: How will you comment in Ruby.

content.rendered:
Ruby comments are non-executable lines in a program. They do not take part in the execution of a program.

Single line comment syntax:

  1. #This is single line comment.  

Multi line comment syntax:

  1. =begin  
  2. This  
  3. is  
  4. multi line  
  5. comment  
  6. =end

excerpt.rendered: Ruby comments are non-executable lines in a program. They do not take part in the execution of a program. Single line comment syntax: #This is single line comment.   Multi line comment syntax: =begin   This   is   multi line   comment   =end

content.rendered: Object is the default root of all Ruby objects. Ruby objects inherit from BasicObject which allows creating alternate object hierarchies.

excerpt.rendered: Object is the default root of all Ruby objects. Ruby objects inherit from BasicObject which allows creating alternate object hierarchies.

content.rendered:
Objects in Ruby are created by calling new method of the class. It is a unique type of method and predefined in Ruby library.

Syntax:

objectName=className.new

excerpt.rendered: Objects in Ruby are created by calling new method of the class. It is a unique type of method and predefined in Ruby library. Syntax:

content.rendered:
Each Ruby class is an instance of Ruby class. Classes in Ruby are first class objects. It always starts with a keyword class followed by the class name.

Syntax:

class ClassName  
codes...  
end

excerpt.rendered: Each Ruby class is an instance of Ruby class. Classes in Ruby are first class objects. It always starts with a keyword class followed by the class name. Syntax:

content.rendered: Ruby method prevent us from writing the same code in a program again and again. Ruby methods are similar to functions in other languages.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby method prevent us from writing the same code in a program again and again. Ruby methods are similar to functions in other languages.

content.rendered:
To use a Ruby method, we need to first define it. It is defined with def and end keyword.

Method name should always start with a lowercase letter.

Syntax:

def methodName  
code...  
end

excerpt.rendered: To use a Ruby method, we need to first define it. It is defined with def and end keyword. Method name should always start with a lowercase letter. Syntax:

content.rendered: Ruby code blocks are called closures in other programming languages. It consist of a group of codes which is always enclosed with braces or written between do…end.

excerpt.rendered: Ruby code blocks are called closures in other programming languages. It consist of a group of codes which is always enclosed with braces or written between do…end.
